content.description:
Yesteryear is a great compression problem that finishes up a highly featured arete.

Sit start deep below the overhang with a small, left hand edge, and a right hand, incut, crimp.  From there, bump the right hand along the arete, hit a great pinch with the left, then stick a big right hand (crux), follow with the left, and then work the remaining arete to reach the top out.
content.protection: A pair of pads will do, the landing is very good.
content.location:
This ascends the west arete of Seed Block.  It shares the same arete as

Four Ways to Wave

.

content.description:
Stand start with a left hand on an edge on the blunt arete and a right hand crimp. From there, move up to a pair of sloping edges (crux), follow with the feet on these edges, gain a left hand sidepull, then move to a thin right hand crimp, bump the left up to another sidepull, get a high foot, hit the lip, and top it out.

There is an alternate top out that escapes out left near the top by using a decent shelf.
content.protection: A few pads will suffice, the immediate landing is great.
content.location: It ascends the vertical north face of Seed Block.

content.description: Sit start with a small left hand edge and a right hand edge that is left over from a broken feature. From there, work up and left through edges to reach a mantel and easy finish up the slab.
content.protection: A pair of pads will work. The landing is pretty good.
content.location: It climbs the west face of the boulder.

content.description:
Sit start with a left hand beneath the overhang on an undercling and a right hand sidepull on the face.  From there, work the good seam left to the arete, then pull onto the slab and finish up the juggy arete.

The problem does not actually climb around the arete, as doing so would likely change the problem's difficulty.  Once at the arete, it climbs up the slab.  The move onto the slab is likely the problem's crux.
content.protection: A few pads and a spot, good landing, there is however a downed-tree behind the problem.
content.location: This climbs the East-facing arete of Seed Block.

content.description:
Bravado Justice ascends a unique, overhung dihedral through the use of technical footwork.

Sit start with hands matched on a thin crimp, flag the right foot, and jam a heel on the ramp. From there, stick a right hand crimp (crux?) at the seam, cross over with the left to another crimp, then make an awkward jump move to get the feet around the corner and gain the big shelf.  At that point, finish up the slab (crux?) by stretching a high, left foot edge while mantling.

The key to this is the heel position with the first move, and the left foot edge with the topout.
content.protection: A few pads should do, the landing is good, but there is large rock that sits behind the topout.
content.location: This ascends the northwest dihedral of Seed Block.
